I dont agree with all your opinions or beliefs but i dont need to. I respect your honesty and input and i value others perspectives. I just sent my 19 and 25 yr old daughters some of hour videos and encouraged them to give you a chance to see how your insight is in large part very accurate on important matters i feel. I hope that they see you as a tool to help them with there trauma and healing and show that most people have the ability to improve there own lives if they fi the work and really look at themselves and the choices that lead you to certain destinations. I hope they see they can empower themselves and start now if they will allow there minds to process new and different ways of seeing there life and future and build n grow as young women by dealing with the bad n dark areas in there life to see the lesson or what you can manifest if you think with intention and actively keep working on themselves akways. They will surpass what took me 43 yrs to learn if they will see how much we gain a lot of times from others and there perspective than we do our own. It opens your reality and gives you more control to change your own life and desires and become a more educated well informed person who is more capable to handle life and goals and understanding the more you listen to others. I mean all walks of life from the lunch lady to a college educated scholar. Seek out new experiences outside your class and race and culture. The more you seek n challenge yourself the more clarity n wisdom n peace and answers i have achieved in my experience. It took me till i was in my late thirties to slow down and truly seek out knowledge and challenge myself especially to grow abd evolve by doing the work. I hope they give you a fair assessment. I respext your perspective and honesty. I agree with a lot of your input and respect you despite any differences we have for being true to yourself and sharing your knowledge and views. I think its important to acknowledge those that are trying to seek the abswres to lifes greatest questions especially than live in a ignorant state of mind of compliance and acceptance and do what society demands. Some people never truly care to ask themselves anything about life or themselves that could change there reality. Most people i think sre scared to face these tough topics and dig deeper for a answers. Hopefully ive taught my girls to question everything. Its part of our purpose on Earth i feel. To always be growing and learning and thinking to be a independent thinker and not a sheep. Its scary and it takes courage and risk and patience but its not a waste of a life. Ill never be famous or well known like yourself im fairly certain but i know that ive become proud of my growth and thirst for knowledge and always challenging myself to see if i can achieve things i once thought was not possible. We are onmly limited by the limits we set for ourselves. I feel im lucky that i finally stopped being my own worst enemy by my regrets and addictions that stunted my ability to seek more from my life. I wasted a lot of years being ignorant and controlled by poison. I havent found a drug i didnt abuse and enjoy. But when i had kids and my husband died i knew i had an obligation to not allow my children to make the same poor choices if i could help it. So i lead by example. Ive literally changed who i am especially the past twelve years. I challenged my kids to make smarter choices so they didnt turn out like me. I never did drugs around them or with them. Its paid off and its the most important purpose i have for my life. To raise these girls to be more than me. I dont mind being there example of what not to do. I know they both have accessed there dad n i expectations and then some. I have gained so much too though. I feel God had a plan for me. Thats why im still alive when so many times i should of not survived my reckless life. Its cause of those girls that i do everything. The bonus is i have found myself and changed so much that i feel like God spared me for some reason too. Why have i bedn so lucky i say sometimes. Ive buried so many i love because of drugs and wasted potential that few see. Do you know what percent of addicts stay clean? Its tragically a very small percentage. But i did it. I will always be proud of that. I have goals and dreams and its been 25 yrs since i had those. I am excited about the future. I want to go back to college and pay it forward. It makes all my pain n struggle have purpose if i can help anyone along the way. Im 43 and i am finally going somewhere and i feel so blessed. Thanks for listening. If you read this. I dont get a lot of praise or seek out compliments often but i want you to know youve been helping me for for four years now. Thanks for being a spokesperson for the masses. You inspiire me and i appreciate all you do. Your changing lives. We need more positive influences in this World like yourself.   Much love Megan - Illinois

I've said this before. The word " but" needs to be removed from your personal vocabulary Jordan.

People using psychedelics/LSD/DMT are just taping into the insula system of the mind, which naturally produces DMT itself.  Which is the same area that schizophrenia comes from when a person damages their amygdala system.  So are we going to accept that schizos are actually talking to entities who are really there in their mind--or are we going to accept that the entities encountered are just produced in the same area of the mind that is connected with dreams and awareness (serotonin in the insula creates melatonin), as the insula is responsible for sleep cycles and releasing hormones to make us tired--notice I say "us" and not it (it stays aware..).    Thus this awareness is the subconscious itself--which does control homeostatic states in both the mind and in the rest of the body and in that emotions are connected to dreams, then this is the area that produces and creates our dreams as well.  The area connected with breathing, heart rate, pleasure/pain response, the "background" feeling of the mind itself.   So taking DMT just allows this "dream" center to be activated while in a waking state.    The problem with taking LSD/DMT is the possibility of damaging the amygdala system which is the cause of schizophrenia itself (where too much stress in a traumatic event, like the death of a parent, can lead to schizophrenia).  Where if one reads the comments below, many will talk of this side-effect.  That and deep depression, as manic-depression is also associated with the insula--and yes, taking substances that simulate too much serotonin will produce mania.    People using psychedelics just doing lab experiments in their own minds with chemicals they don't even have any knowledge of. Notice the "state of union with God" here--a common claim by schizophrenics.    "Emotional awareness. Almost all recent imaging studies of emotion report joint activation of the AIC and the ACC in subjects experiencing emotional feelings, including maternal and romantic love, anger, fear, sadness, happiness, sexual arousal, disgust, aversion, unfairness, inequity, indignation, uncertainty, disbelief, social exclusion, trust, empathy, sculptural beauty, a 'state of union with God', and a hallucinogenic state (induced by ayahuasca). Thus, the AIC is activated not just in association with subjective feelings from the body, but apparently with all subjective feelings."  How do you feel ‚Äî now? The anterior insula and human awareness | Nature Reviews Neuroscience

Happ-i-ness‚Ä®  A good thing; a measure of satisfaction. (See also WELFARE.) Underlying most economic theory is the assumption that people do things because doing so gives them Happ-i-ness.  People want as much happ-i-ness as they can get. However, the more they have, the less difference an additional unit of happ-i-ness will make - there is diminishing MARGINAL happ-i-ness.  Happ-i-ness is not the same as trying to be happy, a political philosophy based on achieving the greatest happ-i-ness of the greatest number.  A tricky question is how to measure happ-i-ness. MONEY does not (entirely) capture it. You can get richer without becoming more satisfied. So some economists have tried to calculate broader measures of happ-i-ness. They have found that people with jobs are much happier than unemployed people.  Low INFLATION also makes people happier. Extra INCOME increases happiness a bit, but not much. In many countries incomes have risen sharply in recent years, but national surveys of subjective well being have stayed flat. Within countries, comparing people across the income distribution, richer does mean happier, but the effect is not large.  Married people are often happier than single people; couples without children happier than couples with; women happier than men; white people happier than black people; well-educated people happier than uneducated people; the self-employed happier than employees; and retired people happier than economically active people. Happ-i-ness generally decreases until you are in your 30s, and then starts rising again. Other economists are dismissive of such studies. They argue that people are rational maximisers of their own happ-i-ness, so, by definition, whatever they do maximizes their happ-i-ness.

For primitive beings like us, life seems to have only one single purpose:  gaining time.  And it is going through time that seems to be also the only real purpose of each of the cells in our bodies. To achieve that aim, the mass of the cells that make up earthworms and human beings has only 2 solutions.  Be immortal, or to reproduce.  If its habitat is not sufficiently favorable or nurturing, the cell will choose immortality. In other words, self-sufficiency and self-management. On the other hand, if the habitat is favorable, they will choose to reproduce.

Psychedelics and the Bible, together or separately? I couldn't imagine reading Ezekiel whilst under the influence of mushrooms...üòÆ Or any other parts. I mean I'm kind of kidding there, the visions and all üòÖ  I've had a couple pretty incredible "heroic" experiences with mushrooms, truly controlled and directed sessions. I will never flinch at telling anyone that I've been taught many important aspects of my personality that were hindering me as a human by means of seriously high dose mushroom experiences.  Regardless of the power they hold, and the positive change they have had in my life, I still am concerned that they fall into the category at 1 Corinthians 6:9,10. There is a list of practices that bar you from the kingdom of God, and one is the practice of sorcery (sometimes druggery, others magic, etc).  That root Greek word it comes from, is pharmakeia. Anyone with a shred of English ability should recognize the similarity of this root word to another English word that we all know the meaning of. I mean, pharmacy \ pharmakeia... I can't say it better than that.  I'll never tell you that you are going to hell if you do shrooms, man, not ever. This is all for me only, coming from a place of serious and sincere spiritual progression. It just scares me, regardless of the immense positive effect that shrooms had on me, because I'm not the judge or lawmaker, you know?  When I consider 2 Corinthians 11:14 alongside it, in which Satan and his ministers disguise themselves as angels of light, etc... I can't help but think of the great spirit light of the desert, the spirit of the forest, the great teacher, you name it they all refer to spiritual things or teachers. I've even encountered some of the "entities" that reside in that beyond, they're real and they're there man, you'll never convince me otherwise.  So I guess I'm just sharing my knowledge and my own personal conviction regards the two and adding mushrooms to the Bible or vice versa. I'm not saying anyone's going to hell if they practice shtoomery, I once was a very seasoned psychonsut in the psilocybin realms. These are just my thoughts and fears surrounding what mushrooms taught me about myself, what I've learned by reading the Bible and the incredible potential for psychedelics to be held up as a "panacea", which it isn't, though they are immensely powerful.  I don't think Satan has any proclivities whatsoever to do something immensely good for humans in order to trick us into doing something that defies God's thinking and wishes. That sounds like exactly the sort of thing Satan would do to us, it's the same thing he did to Eve in the garden.  As much as I once revered the shroom as an incredibly helpful tool that brought me out of a very dark place, they scare me now because of the possible source of their power. Demons may not be physically on earth now, but once upon a time they were here on earth having taken human form, with powers beyond any human, power to create or twist a creation into something as powerful as a sort of spiritual gateway like shrooms. One that leads into a realm we do not belong, even though the effects are overwhelmingly positive on the whole, at the surface level.   Best wishes and if you're on the road to recovery via a psychedelic treatment plan then so be it man üòä I'm happy for yoiu that you're getting a help that you've probably been seeking for years and finally found. I know, because I've been there. I just can't not say that out loud though, when the two are mentioned together, the Bible (God) and psychedelic treatments. It personally scares me and if I were not to say something, I feel I would be held accountable. üòä  Much love to all, no judgement here whatsoever. I wouldn't have made my way back to God via study of the Bible if I hadn't taken the shroom journey that I did. I just don't think I can recommend it with a good conscience.‚ù§

Holy shit. Jordan Peterson. You are so good: you are such a good, good man. However, you are laboring under a fundamental misunderstanding of maleficence that could be cleared up with one word: LEARN. You encountered a "bad trip." It's okay, it's not the end of the world. I can tell you FOR SURE that maleficence didn't mean you harm. Rather, in another world, it IS your teacher.  In the story of Cain and Able, one of the brothers offered valuable sacraments to his God expecting a blessing in return. He can't fathom why God turned aside all of his gifts and condemned him. Here is the question: who is the gift giver? All God asks is that you come unto GOD. He doesn't want your shit! Sit somewhere, and breathe like a mf'r and contemplate Goodness; rise above any natural thoughts you may have. Then. Simply. Meet God. Let it happen. (HUGE hint: God is NOT NOT NEVER CAN BE maleficence). A lot of people emphasize speaking TO God, the biggest hint I can give is to LISTEN. There is a place Beyond, and you can only get there from INSIDE. You will have peace, IF you are called. Jordan Peterson... I believe things have been taken from you for a REASON. You COULD be, and have the unique capacity to understand and transcend Everything. Think I'm speaking gibberish? Even before the Bible, there was the wisdom of God. Do as I say, and maybe we can talk someday. I would enjoy your newfound perspective, and how you read this from a different point of reference afterwards.  Cheers. - Everything (a nobody)

The first time I ate cubensis mushrooms, It changed me for the better, I'm literally swelling with tears as I recall that experience.  The fear, low self esteem, self-doubt and every feeling of worthlessness that was beaten, shouted, threatened, intimidated, abused and traumatized into me from as far back as I can remember- 3-4 years old, just seemed to dissolve. It was like when you toss an Alka seltzer tablet into a gallon of warm water.  Walls were vaporized, dams were breached and the waters flowed, bridges were materialized over these flowing waters. It was f*cking beautiful!!  I was free, for the first time in those 19 years of life, I felt truly free.  I can truly, truly and honestly say that I felt what Love was, because I became Love and suddenly realized that is what I always had been, Unconditional Love.  That's why I was always the scapegoat, the whipping boy, the easy target.  I was made aware that I endured all that suffering, not because I was the self-hating flaws of character and unhealed traumas they all projected onto me, but it was because I was blameless and divine, pure empathy, hope and kindness, I was everything that they were lacking, everything they were not. I was like that little pup that gets kicked around and starved physically/mentally/spiritually, yet still comes around, sits next to and tries to love and comfort that same abusive monster when it recognizes their sorrow.  It wasn't me, it was never me that was the problem and I didn't deserve that abuse, or the bag of guilt and trauma that I had been carrying around everywhere until that point.  So I set it  down right then and there, it wasn't my bag to carry, not my load to bear.  The following weeks were a series of setting boundaries and burning bridges.  I was assertive and decisive, if you didn't help push or pull, you were brushed aside.  Where before I cowered and avoided conflict and confrontation in hope that the storm would quietly pass me by, I now would rise to look it dead in the eye and dare it to do its worst, like LT. Dan in Forrest Gump,  fear haf left the building. Of course it took a while longer to completely round up all those clever traumas and triggers that had hidden themselves in the recessed corners and darkest crevices of the shadow Self,  that the ego conveniently glazed over.   It is said that psychedelics are shortcuts to connecting with the higher consciousness or g_dhead, and therefore unearned wisdom/enlightenment.  But I don't agree with that wholly, because sometimes you have to do what you need to do for yourself. This knowledge can be attained if you pay attention to the omens and synchronicities that your Intuitive perception just can't seem to ignore.  They're attempting to lead you to water, it's up to you whether you choose to drink or not.   If you do choose to partake in these substances, do it mindfully, set an Intention.  Whether it's for recreation or healing of mind, body or spirit, or all three, declare what you wish to get from that experience, speak it. Respect and honor the organic and inorganic, for their part in the experience.  Maybe meditate for a few minutes on the purpose or goal of the experience.  You can heal, rid yourself of vices or habits that are detrimental to your being.  You can gain Wisdom and get answers that you may have, as long as those answers don't infringe on your free Will.  Just be conscientious and have a safe trip. üíõüåû‚òùÔ∏è

I know this is a year old, but I really believe this man is a sweet  gift - (although, I am sure he doesn't think that way). He gets deep. He gets very deep‚Ä¶   But! He's not afraid to criticize himself‚Ä¶ he's not afraid to show emotion‚Ä¶ he certainly is not afraid to say that he just does not know the answer... or hasn't found something - yet.  Ever the seemingly optimist, though - he  keeps looking.  There's not many people like that. This world is full of "look at me, look at me - I have all the answers" types.  Dr. Peterson is simply trying to make sense of this unfathomable thing we call life - and how the brain, outside influences, world views & individual experiences work in each human being. He starts with the human and works himself all the way through to "the world".  A very tough job. But, a job that someone has to love in order to even do it in the first place. Never mind the love he has for the people he's educating and helping.  No, I don't worship him. I worship Jesus Christ‚Ä¶ But, I certainly highly respect him and believe he was meant to be heard. A.K.A.:  a gift from God!  There are many people that are extremely intelligent and they share truth(s) - or the seemingly unending search for it -   However, Dr. Peterson presents that knowledge (or search) with explanations, stories, writing books, conferences, speeches; all the while exhibiting humility and grace while anchoring himself (mostly) with what we call H0PE.  Why does a man kill himself? He loses hope. Without hope, we have nothing.  I think Dr. Peterson always brings hope with him - wherever he goes. If not for himself, surely for his listeners/readers.  Hope resonates in everything he does; in his educated writings, life lessons, experiences, beliefs; even the things he can't find or answer. He doesn't pretend to know everything. He is so down to earth, a child could relate to him.  If you have no hope, you have nothing. Not even hope of hope.  Thank you, Dr. Peterson; for all that you do. People have told you that you actually saved their lives. And when that was brought up in this video, you could feel his emotions through the screen‚Ä¶ You could feel how much that means to him. That alone must make all his work extremely worthwhile.  Now, I may not have accurately described Jordan Peterson. If he were to see this, he may not agree with a thing or two. But that's what I see. That being said‚Ä¶ I hope we keep hearing from him. He has definitely helped me! (MDD)  If it were possible, for everyone's life he has touched -  we could come together and personally thank him and hug him - We would need a humongous venue!  You are most assuredly loved,  Dr. Jordan B Peterson !  Respectfully, All your students of life üíõü§éüß°

Also, Genesis is not about the "creation of the universe" as some great metaphysical vision. It is literally about the beginning of time for humans, which is specifically about a time when the main sequence star that we now call the sun backlit the planet Saturn in such a way as to produce a revolving crescent. This was the "wheel of time" during which humans could, for the first time in their evolution, mark the passage of time, and the time sequence moved from night time when the crescent was brightest and strongest to noon when it was weakest and dimmest (in a counterclockwise direction). And the "waters above" and the "waters below" were visually present as vast images in the sky during the "polar configuration" in which the planetary sequence was Saturn, Venus, Mars, and Earth all in line with the northern pole of the Earth. And this ties together all of the mythologies and archetypes with the advanced physics of the Electric Universe. When all other theories have proved impossible the one that's left, no matter how improbable, is the truth.

Look, dragons are a universal archetype all over the world for the same reason that the thunderbolt is universal (and it's not a lightning bolt). These were manifestations of continent sized plasma discharges in the atmosphere and between planets that were visible to nearly everyone on earth. This was "the war in heaven" recorded in nearly every culture. It isn't a metaphor. It's an actual memory that we have suppressed due to trauma and the metaphors are a coping mechanism. One estimate is that it killed all but about 2% of the population of the Earth. We live in an "electric universe" that is  far less stable than we imagine, and we need to rehabilitate our memories with all deliberate haste.

The dilemma that seems to be at the center of his "mission" is created by the impulse to see metaphors everywhere. Like Jung he reasons that the similarity of archetypes is a reflection of the human condition, but that's a rather narrow understanding because neither Jung nor JP can identify a real provocation for these universal archetypes, and relatedly they can't formulate a theory about why the celestial planetary bodies are so central to the expression of all of these archetypes, when they're such tiny points of light as to be virtually imperceptible to nearly everyone. Well, as Dave Talbott suggests "If the words and images seem strange to you, there is a reason for this. Our world was once a vastly different place. To experience this won't hurt you, and there is nothing to fear."

The Purpose Of Life  As with any philosophy: the moment a person sees a flaw in one aspect - the whole thing will, and should, collapse.  For example, The Principle of Polarity says: anything that is polarised, such as black and white, are basically the same thing - colour.  However, that does not mean black is white or white is black when we say they are both aspects of colour.  Black is black and it always will be black. White is white and it always will be white.  Of course ... it is possible to see both as grey but this (colour) is still black and white pixles / areas creating the illusion of grey.  This goes for everything we perceive - including dreams - since light is light and darkness is darkness regardless of subjective identification.  Thus, all philosophy is rendered worthless - because it makes perception malleable within the expression of delusion.  Perception, without delusion, allows all of reality to function eternally.  Therefore, the purpose of life (in this world) is to engender an eternal estate in preparation for the next world.  This is to say, we are required to leave any delusional estate (sin) to embrace the perfected mindset (Christ).  ...because the next world is eternal.  This reality will ultimately pass away - along with those who embraced some delusional estate.

Creation narratives of many kinds can give insights into the meaning and purpose of life in many ways.  One part of a creation story that I am familiar with has come to have profound significance to me on many fronts: scientific and religious. Allow me to share it with you. See what emerges from your mind as you meditate on this conversation:   ELOHIM: Jehovah, Michael, now that the earth is formed, divided, and beautified, and vegetation is growing thereon, return and place beasts upon the land: the elephant, the lion, the tiger, the bear, the horse, and all other kinds of animals--fowls in the air in all their varieties, fishes of all kinds in the waters, and insects and all manner of animal life upon the earth.  Command the beasts, the fowls, the fishes, the insects, all creeping things, and other forms of animal life to multiply in their respective elements, each after its kind, and every kind of vegetation to multiply in its sphere, that every form of life may fill the measure of its creation and have joy therein. Call your labors the fifth day, and bring me word.  JEHOVAH: It shall be done, Elohim. Come, Michael, let us go down.  MICHAEL: We will go down, Jehovah.

Dr. Peterson, I am a fan. I have come to listen to your podcasts and motivational clips for an hour or two or three nearly every day. I wish I could share with you mountains of information that I have gleaned over many years of experience on virtually every topic you discuss. The call to challenge young men to make the world a better place by encouraging competence and speaking truth, on recognizing the uniqueness of every soul and serving the least among us ring deeply within me. I lack the distinction and achievements that those you interview possess, yet I am not without insights and experience that I think you would find valuable. I am a 73-year-old retired general surgeon who is self-employed part time as a medical researcher. I am also a lay minister or a priesthood holder in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. I served a two year mission for my church in Chile from 1969 to 1971 and on a church high council in New York City. I closed my surgical practice in the intermountain west in 1996 after suffering a mid-brain bleed that was complicated by acute hydrocephalus requiring emergency placement of a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt that left me with chronic drowsiness, impaired executive function, and some other problems but without obvious impact on my movement or speech. I worked for 13 years after my stroke at many odd jobs including working in a junior high and two career colleges teaching health, mathematics, anatomy and physiology, health administration, chemistry, biology, microbiology, etc. until difficulties planning my lecture schedule and submitting final grades on time led to my dismissal and finally a declaration of totally disability. I wrote my senior thesis at the University of California San Diego School of Medicine on evidence based medicine and medical outcome research as it relates to hypertension care in eleven New York City voluntary hospitals. My advisor was the developer of the health status index and its use as a measure of good or bad health policies. I did my internship at a hospital near Greenwich Village in Manhattan and did a fellowship in cardiothoracic surgery in Columbia, Missouri. My wife, a Juilliard-trained pianist, and our four children are exceptionally bright but were found to have an inductive learning problem that severely threatened their academic, professional, and social futures. I was told that I needed to summarize all that my children read and help them find the main ideas of what they regarded as confusing collections of random facts and to do research projects with them in history and science. I spent 6 to 12 hours a day tutoring them for 17 years. All their projects and research papers won state and/or national prizes. They were on a wide variety of topics including the historical context of Edgar Allen Poe's A Cask of Amontillado, Thomas Jeffersons views on slavery, the role of ancestors in the Revolutionary War and the Pequot War, just war theory as well as bridge and roof truss design, human insulation systems, and the mathematical modelling of break dancing. Each of my children qualified for scholarships--in large part due to my poverty--at premier colleges: Amherst College, Yale, MIT, and Harvard. All are married with children and gainfully employed. My oldest son teaches art and animation at two colleges in Chicago. My daughter graduated from Yale in Theater Arts and Acting from the Manhattan School Music in classical voice. She has won a Tony Award and received a Grammy Nomination. My two younger sons obtained Ph.D.s in mechanical engineering from MIT. One is a tenured professor in mechanical engineering and the other is a reseach engineer for Ford Motor Company. Talk about joy!! Things could have been so much worse for them. I am divorced but still interact significantly with my precious wife of 35 years. I was exposed to diethylstilbestrol in utero, and in 2002 developed a need to cross-dress that proved extremely difficult to control. St. John's Wort and Vyvanse eliminated completely my need to cross-dress for a year and a half but led to a clinically rather minor but ominous right frontal lacunar stroke in 2009 that required that I permanently discontinue these meds.  I cross-dress only in private but have been involved with trans issues that go against the current trends now for many years. Still my wife was nauseated by even the idea of my cross-dressing and decided to divorce me. I have no property and no car and have received a considerable amount of help from the welfare system of my faith over the years. Nevertheless, I regard myself as rich beyond my wildest dreams. I would love to spend some time on many topics with you including how to deal with economic inequality, challenging all men and women young and old to actively participate in promoting and implementing Christian values and learning to living a life of obedience to the laws and ordinances that Christ taught his church to follow, faith, repentance and sacrifice, consecration, virtue, and purity that prepares all in the human family past, present, and future, including the least among us, for a joyous eternal life together through taking responsibility to serve our families, our churches, and our communities and through taking upon us the name of Jesus Christ and always remembering the atonement and sacrifice of Jesus Christ.  My email is jameshopkins21@gmail.com

‚ÄúIt is really something that you can‚Äôt control your conscience. So what is it really?  It is not you. You are accountable to it.‚Äù    As a student of early Buddhist literature this really struck me as having some parallel to the characteristic of ‚Äúnot-self‚Äù as expressed in the Samyutya Nikaya  (SN 22.59, Anatta-lakkhana Sutta) as well as the opening verses in the Dhammapada ‚ÄúMind precedes all states ‚Ä¶ speak or act with an impute mind and suffering follows.‚Äù  I mention this because I think it is another tradition that speaks to the same problem ‚Äî of how near to organize your life, a tradition that admits that suffering as a basic truth. So, if we see that there is suffering in the world and we see that our thoughts and feelings and perceptions are not really our own, how should we act?  And the Buddha tells us that we suffer for our misdeeds and flourish for our wholesome actions. Furthermore, the texts reveal that nothing is really under our perfect control so we avoid speaking or acting when our mind is clouded.   I know Dr Peterson avoids referring to Buddhism, being a non-expert. But this is wonderfully rich stuff that these religious traditions have deep parallels and that there is literature preserved from early Buddhism that speaks to the mechanisms of conscience, the importance of ethical behavior, and  the middle way between holding yourself too tightly and avoiding accountability.

JP is fine if you don‚Äôt mind sitting through hours and hours of wondering and preponderances, thinkings out loud that just go round and round in circles and never really land on anything solid. While he‚Äôs wandering around all this mysterious, ephemeral stuff there always feels like there‚Äôs something good coming, but it rarely seems to get there. He might eventually alight on something that sounds familiar but they are often fleeting moments that need more flesh on the bones to be anything like convincing. He rarely provides this and is off into the mystical fog again leaving you with nothing to really grasp onto.   It‚Äôs telling the truth that keeps the world from falling apart? Really? In my experience it‚Äôs mostly fudging, stretching, massaging and evading the truth that keeps the world turning, but for the occasional moments when it is actually essential. I want my children to learn to always tell the truth? No, I want them to learn when it is appropriate to tell the truth. Someone who religiously always tells the truth as he sees it (given that there is often no guarantee that what you think is the truth is, in fact, the truth) is a person with under-developed social skills, you might say, autistic

At 1:15:57, Dr. Peterson says "You know in the deepest part of your heart that if you don't tell the truth, the world falls apart. And that's actually true. You know I talked about unearned wisdom. It's no trivial matter to understand that. You know Dostoevsky said 'Everyone is responsible for everything that happens to them and everything that happens to everyone else as well.' And you know that's an insane statement and he was a very extreme person but it's also true."  Earlier in the interview, Dr. Peterson talks about how the story of Cain and Abel really struck a blow to him that he hasn't quite ever got over. I had that Biblical story queued up in my mind when I heard him say what I quoted and he was tearing up as he said it. I paused the video to pull out my Bible and I re-read where God asks Cain where is brother is and knowing full well he had just murdered him, Cain says "I know not (where he is). Am I my brother's keeper?" (Genesis 4v9) God does not answer his question because it wasn't asked with the intent to be answered. It was said out of sarcasm and I believe also because, as Jesus later revealed, "out of the overflow of the heart, the mouth speaks" (Luke 6v45). I wonder and can only imagine what Cain was feeling when he uttered those words, what he discovered about his heart in that moment. For us today, what if us not taking responsibility for our own lives leads to the destruction or even deaths of those we claim to love. Am I my brother's keeper? Yes. Yes you are, and so am I, and if we abdicate that responsibility, it's not just us that will suffer for it, and so, we press on (Philippians 3v13-14).  Thank you for this interview with Dr. Peterson. As always, I found his insights very enlightening and most encouraging to keep pushing back the darkness, even if just one inch at a time.

Regarding resentment, I have a slightly different take than what he explains. Yes it‚Äôs stressful and sometimes you need to shelf the issue, or that you need personal growth, but I believe this overlooks a glaring alternate need to figure out how to rectify the situation instead of ignoring it. Often the resentment, in my opinion, comes from an inability or inexperience in dealing with the cause. For example, you may have social anxiety and lose your focus on what you wanted to say to someone who cornered you and caused the resentment; in retrospect, with experience and knowledge in expressing your feelings you can have a positive outcome instead. This contrasts to the theory here that the resentment is irreconcilable through ones own lack of abilities in handling the conflict, not averting and having a ‚Äúfalse peace ‚Äú.

Not sure if I'm a bit of a softy or a touch too sensitive.  Bit I'd really like to put this out there and see if there's any other living soul sharing this particular sentiment of mine with regards to Peterson's current, I shall say, "condition", for lack of a better word.  And I don't mean that in the slightest way offensively or condescendingly.   I'm in awe of this man's output of practical and actually applicable wisdom into the world in general and into the lives of many of his followers, including myself, rather more particularly.   However, the sentiment I have set out to share in here is that of sheer pain and horrid misery I feel pouring out of Peterson's voice tone and pitches, particularly during his interviews that I've watched, which came out starting from the early parts of the 2020 and onwards.   I mean, I've heard, seen and read of the psychosomatic struggles this monumental man had to go through.  And, although I do not yet possess any specifics as to the true nature and extent of his struggles, I somehow get these vibes of true hardships, utter pain, unimaginable misery, painful disdain and shattering desparation by watching him and even more so by listening to him.  Especially when I detect those relatively long pauses of his when he's trying to (in my understanding) recollect and recompose himself.  Coming right back in from those silent intervals, he has the most heart breaking of voice pitches, its like I, unwillingly, get a glimpse right into the edge or the pinnacle of his eminent, on setting internal collapse.   I usually end up putting a real internal fight with myself at that point not to break down in tears myself from this tsunami of pain I feel coming out of this man's voice.   I was simply wondering if that's some sort of an imaginary over blown thing that is probably more self inflicted in my state of being or whether anybody else out there gets this vibe of heart melting suffering pouring from Peterson.   BTW, I wanted to put particular emphasis on the fact that I do not feel sorry in any sense for the man.  And certainly do not pitty him.  And don't think that any sane person would ever dare to have these feelings towards him.   It's just that I kinda hurt listening to him.   It's like in some ultra unacceptable way I feel his own bone shuttering pain crawling through my own body and soul.   So?  Is my perception purely a subjective personal thing, or is there any hint of objective reality to it?

Anger (or externalized depression) is revealed in one's very thoughts and patterns which of course speaks to one's unresolved trauma and pain.  Additionally, the reactive and unaware emphasis on others' intentions as opposed to your own sense of authentic self, equilibrium, equanimity, goodwill and belief in the common good is already an indication that one is unmoored from their true self.  When others malign us, our response to their actions has nothing to do with their actions.  It may seem that way (that our emotional reaction is a result of their perceived provocation) but the truth is that if we become rattled by their actions then we fail to not only respect the authentic child within but have given them our own agency.  Indeed, this is why anger is so often a hallmark of a very precarious sense of self.   Alternately, consider those who work (not fight, a critical distinction) for human rights.  Would they be able to make their incremental gains if they allowed tremendous systemic obstacles or individual criticisms to distract and provoke them?  You see, our wellness becomes plainly obvious by our very emphasis of reality: is it about others' thoughts, opinions or treatment of us (Peterson's notion of 'suffering') or rather about how we contribute to the common good, regardless of the hostility, admiration or apathy of others?  Building community requires integration of the self which paradoxically relies on selflessly serving others and the natural environment., therein lies wellness and indeed the pathway to authenticity.

... I respect and admire Dr. Peterson a great deal, however, as time goes on, there does seem to be an unusual blind spot regarding 'women'. I don't mean the abstraction of the feminine principal inherent in the yin/yang of which he's quite capable of speaking, I mean Peterson's well-meaning and on-going articulation about the male spiritual journey through life ...   He obviously KNOWS that story very well. It's clear to most observers that he, himself, is on such a hero's journey.   No problem with that.   However, his foundational Biblical framework, (as the substantial religious structure of Western civilization), increasingly fails to apply - or appeal - to women.   Think about that.  That's half of the human species.  And, surely, that's a problem.   It's not just the inherent  'patriarchy' of the Biblical doctrine itself, it's about the greater misunderstanding, (even implied dismissal), of the innately deep difference - and potential - of women.   As a woman, I can hear and understand HIM, but, I wonder increasingly, is he really capable of hearing - and genuinely understanding - the spiritual journey of the heroine?   And yes, the sexes ARE different, from start to finish.

27:16 I disagree with peterson on this one. Marriages have become pointless celebrations more props to support an otherwise useless industry that has no reason to exist other than the false sense of worth we give to it, so we're willing to waste huge sums or resources because we don't consider unions to be important unless we do. Thats never how it used to be, and is appalling. A marriage certificate is a piece of paper, thats it. If you require some big celebration to prove to yourself or others the worthiness of the relationship then it isn't one that your ready to take to that level of permanence.    I think our over dependence on these exuberant rituals is one of the primary reasons why divorce rates are skyrocketing. We get married way before we're ready for it, because we have this false image in our heads about what marriage is supposed to be. Like many other things in society we fit ourselves into this mold, and then when we realize we can't fit that mold everything falls apart and we then dig deeper into convincing ourselves that we want something when we really don't.    There is a difference between not marrying and completely isolating yourselves from the outside community, which we do a damn good job of now anyways so his point is really a moot one in context.

Hah! Well...today's Christians sometimes accuse C.S. Lewis of not being a christian either.  People have adopted the mindset that if you dont use the exact same belief statements that you couldn't possibly share the same faith.  And yet a close, contextual, serious look at sacred scriptures reveals authors with very different concepts of the divine and how the divine interacts with us.

¬†@booksquid856¬† well those people are crazy lol. The early church spread itself over several different cultural and ethnic groups, I'm certain they didn't all think the same way, and if they were wrong the rule of charity was applied and they were taught.

¬†@booksquid856¬† The basics were unified pretty early on in the Nicene and Apostle's Creeds. I like Jordan Peterson, but I just don't think he would affirm Jesus as Savior and Lord. Yes, we could go on endlessly parsing out what it means to even say that... but I have to believe the Holy Spirit allows even people of severely diminished mental capacity who can't endlessly philosophize about these concepts to have an understanding which transcends words. I think charity in all non-essential things is, well, essential. I think what bothers me about JP sometimes is that you can't stand outside looking "through" things forever, to borrow a concept from Lewis. A window is for seeing through to something, as Lewis said. Endless analysis and total skepticism (even charitable skepticism like JP's) are dead ends (or rather an infinite dead end).

¬†@booksquid856¬† It's possible I'm wrong, too, surely. Jesus was clear that a preeminent quality of heaven would be surprise... surprise at who is there (and perhaps who is not). The first will be last and the last will be first. Only God sees the heart.

The story of Cain and Abel is very interesting to me as well.  Adam and Eve ate from the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil, so they experienced that in the most shocking way within a few decades when one of their sons murdered another.  In scripture, Abel gave his ‚Äúfirstfruits‚Äù from his flock, a true sacrifice, while scripture seems to imply Cain just gave out of his abundance, not a true sacrifice (heart was not in it).  Not a lot expressed here, but this makes sense given later books as well as New Testament emphasis on pointing your heart to God through Christ.

For those with a faith...  Genesis 2:15, God creates man and places him in the garden to ‚Äútend‚Äù (nurture) and ‚Äúkeep‚Äù (protect) it.  Adam was given life and a calling (a work based on his particular gifting and attributes).  Genesis 2:21, God created woman to be man‚Äôs ‚Äúhelper‚Äù (council, adviser) based on her unique gifting and attributes.  So when Eve first saw Adam, he was in the presence of God and actively working in his calling.  People are miserable in a lot of relationships because the man looks for a mate before he embarks on his mission.  He gets a lot of necessary character development when he trains and applies his gifts to his calling (patience, perseverance, mental/emotional security, self-confidence, etc.). If he rushes into relationship before that process even starts, the woman can be left feeling she has to do everything in the relationship, leading to misery and resentment.

Totally agree with the initial post here. There's something just riveting that cannot be contained or explained or nailed down exactly about watching/listening to Dr. Jordan Peterson speak. His existence is honestly something that gives me hope for humanity and continually CONTINUALLY inspires me without fail. Somehow anytime I listen to him , I walk away with multiple new nuggets of truth and kernels of wisdom which I then wrestle with and chew on for the rest of the day/week/month/even years sometimes. This man's brain is just a gift from God and I pray for him always to get to know Christ in a way that (don't attack me here, this is just my perception after having seen hundreds of interviews & talks of his), ‚Äî but I don't believe the way he conceptualizes or relates to the actual person of Jesus Christ is exactly what most Christians (the ones who have gotten what the Bible is saying right at least), ‚Äî I just haven't yet seen that he has accepted certain realities of that version or concept of Christ. I'm not saying he doesn't have religious sentiments. He obviously believes in a higher good and in the concept of value and that there is something strange profound and mystical and even religious about our every day lives and the experience of being a person on earth. But I am just saying  that I will continually pray that he be moved and have whatever experience or revelation that he personally needs on order to make the final step and accept/conclude/surrender to the exhistance of an all living God , the God of the Bible, the God who sacrificed his son so that we could all avoid damnation and enjoy eternal life in that God's presence. I'm sure some people will disagree with me and claim that "oh no , Jordan is a Christian, it's written all over his biblical lecture series. How could someone lecture like that on the word of God and Not be a Christian?!"....well these people should also note that when he is asked about whether he Believes in God, his answers don't at all line up with the simplicity that would come out of the mouth of a true believing Christian. And no that is not a consequence of his superior intellect or that he thinks about spiritual things on a deeper level than us mere every day people. No. For any and all people, no matter where they land on the spectrum of IQ/intelligence, this answer really (if they are indeed a true Bible believing actual Christ following God fearing Christian) would simply be a YES. YES I BELIEVE IN GOD. or Yes I have a relationship with the creator and I have come to know his son Jesus who is King of all. This is not at all an attack on Peterson. He is on his own journey and I'm sure a person with a heart as amazingly big and beautiful as his will come to this realization eventually. I mean, God made this man so bright and articulate and his lectures have brought many people back to church ! So yes I believe God smiles upon his work , and obviously God loves all of his children but yes there is lots of goodness and a sort of spiritual essence emanating from his talks a lot of the time. That is all great.. I am simlly pointing this out bc I'm sick of hearing true well-meaning christians talk about Dr. P as though he is a devout 100% believer in Jesus. What he actually says (quite frequently in fact) is that "he acts as if God exhists".......that right there PRETTY MUCH is saying that he is either skeptical that He does exhist, or quite sure that He does not exist at all. People just want to believe Jordan has a relationship with Christ bc it fits better in their head as the story of who this man is.  Like they want him to be some kind of posterboy or spokesperson that can represent Christianity and actually in a positive way. The fact is just that He really is not technically truly what I consider to be a real Christian. And tbat is NOT a criticism or judgement of him. I am not saying he is somehow a villain for not having fully converted yet. I simply wish to clarify to people what his beliefs are and are not, and to clear up all this stuff I see online about him being a freaking Christian. Like it's like people just assume it and have no idea what they are talking about. Just bc someone read the Bible that does Not make them a Christian. Followers of Jesus know this. The ones that pay attention and obsess over JBP's lectures and work the way I do out of fascination, admiration, and appreciation will know exactly what I mean and they will have noticed these comments online too and will also note the inaccuracy of such misunderstandings of so many many well meaning (assumedly) Christian folks out there.   Point is not to denegrste Jordan or even call him out for what he does or does not believe or adhere to. All I'm saying  is that if you are a follower of Jesus and a fan of Jordan Peterson , your prayers for his faith to be fully formed are needed and can make powerful changes so don't stop praying for him bc he is an amazing great one of a kind beautiful human soul but he needs a savior and to come to FULL and ACTUAL acceptance of the Biblical truths (the gospel) just as much as any of us sinners down here on earth.  He has integrity and the heart of a lion. His mind is fascinating and he is a blessing to get to listen to on YouTube! His exhistance makes my life unquestioningly and exceedingly better and more fulfilling. Sometimes I'd even say his exhistance feels like it makes life more worth living, just to make it clear how huge of a fan I am of him. So don't read this as a dig on him in any ANY sense. Quite the opposite. I would like to see him in heaven one day. I am certain God has plans to reveal himself in more fullness to Jordan in just such a way that is just what Jordan would need it to be to be  convinced. All I'm saying is I will never stop praying for you Dr. Peterson, not only for you to receive Jesus fully as your Lord and savior and to start to have those bible stories run through your veins in new and exciting ways that they can actually literally only do for those once they are a believer. That is the work of the Holy Spirit. Some truths are only able to be revealed to people once they  truly have faith. I love you Dr. Peterson. I mean I really really am glad you are here on this planet the same time that I am, and I appreciate the work you do more than I can ever express. You give me hope for humanity. But those words fall flat to how my heart and mind truly feel when it comes to what you've done in this world . Thank you for doing all you can and for making the world a  better place. You're awesome. I really really love you and will never cease my prayers for God to shine his light on you in whatever way you need that will speak to your heart the way He has spoken to me and  many other TRUE TRUE believers out there.  Actual Christians will know what I mean.    Stay you. Peace from someone who's heart and mind you've set on fire and is just grateful to have the internet and a phone to get to watch you anytime I want. What an absolute blessing. Cannot thank you enough . Cannot thank God enough for all he has done for me including bringing my awareness to your work.. peace be with you and your lovely family. Just discovered this incredible man's videos a couple days ago.  I'm saddened to see this strong and seemingly very good man in an emotionally weakened condition.  I can't help wondering whether his recent struggles are the consequence of living such a public, high-powered life.  I also wonder about some of his medical decisions that might be related to his intellectual views.  In my opinion, it's very important for anyone so thoughtful, smart and concerned with causation and truth that they do not get ahead of themselves, intellectually.  Personally, I feel Dr. Peterson would do well taking some of his own advice and rely on the competence from established academic heirrarchies when he ventures outside of his own field ambitiously.  Like most academic disciplines, evolutionary biology has rich theoretical traditions which, I believe, are very important for him to grasp (including practically, i.e. beyond a philosophy/history of science level.) Not just for extending his views from psychology into philosophy and neurobiology, but also possibly for informing his own medical decision-making.  Because of the great depth and breadth of its subject matter, evolution is loaded with both entrenched, gate-keepers and fringe charlatans, a neo-Darwinian minefield.  Pass auf, sagt man auf Deutsch.

It‚Äôs funny how a lot of this stuff is just beyond the border of provable science, and how in fact a lot of it has very strong evidence against it, but conversations like this make some of it seem completely legitimate, logical, acceptable and true. It‚Äôs either a subtle ignorance or a subtle gaslighting or both, but some (not all) of the underlying beliefs/ideas/opinions shown here are in fact dangerous, or at the very least, not fleshed out enough to protect listeners from misinterpretation. It plays into this whole super-subculture of like centrist libertarianism and self-help and historically selective narratives and omissions, pseudoscience, and sort of oddball charlatan philosophy billed as highly evolved social theory and critical thought. The problem for me is that there‚Äôs some nuance to my position in that I agree with bits and pieces, but strongly disagree and am appalled by the just complete lack of skepticism both between Tim and Jordan and between them and the audience in regards to some of the discussion. It‚Äôs definitely a circlejerk sort of vibe peppered with buzzwords and some ideas that on the surface seem interesting or something but are realistically ignorant or dangerous or completely disproven.
Internet discussions and lectures have their limitations.  There's something to be said for the written word and peer review, despite all the orthodoxy.

¬†@carlbumba57¬† Agreed. And I will say that not all of what they talked about is just totally made up pseudoscience or something. There was some legitimate, proven science and good personal psychology advice on the part of Mr. Peterson, but I also (personally believe) that there was way too much of what I tried to describe in my first comment. My main issue is that there's no accountability. Just from reading the comments it looks like many of the hundreds of thousands of people who consumed this content just ate it up without batting an eye. It's like people hear from guys like this (assertive white male experts in their fields), and just assume none of what they say could be false, misconstrued, conjecture, gaslighting, or anything to question.  I do think Peterson is extremely intelligent, full of profound wisdom and interesting ideas and psycho-emotional awareness/insight that could help anyone understand themselves and/or the world better, but I also think the sheer deference people give to him and the lack of thoughtful critique of some of the things he says is worrisome.  I do appreciate his vulnerability as well.

His first introduction to "serious thought" was "One Day of Ivan Denisovich" by Solzhenitsyn? Wow... That explains a lot. There is very little thought in that book. It's actually all about the experience. And sure, it's great fiction, but historicity of his Arhipelago Gulag work,  is quite frankly, dubious. There are instances where it's not only not historical, but outright deceitful, such as when the revolts of Ukrainian Nationalists were claimed to be entirely peaceful. Those were documented as some of the most bloody and violent, where not only the guards but other prisoners too were murdered if they refused to cooperate. The guy's whole critique of Marx is based on a tiny pamphlet called "The Communist Manifesto". Jordan peterson thinks he can critique Marx and Engels when he has never even read The Capital or any other of their multiple works. And sure, I do agree with a lot of things he says, and I find many of his sentiments well observed such as "the truly moral individuals - you don't mess with them, they are capable of being reasonably dangerous). However he so badly lacks humility that he has practically never answered a question with "I'm not an expert in this field", but rather started raving on his side on the matter, often completely ignorant and  uninformed,  and factually erroneous. I like him in many ways, but also in many ways I find him repulsive, this whole guru aspect, with giving ultimate life advice to young men, - totally unwarranted and wrong on so many levels. And him getting into Dostoyevski early also sheds light on his totally erroneous line of reasoning where he ties morality's origins to religious thought, when all available research in Behavioural Science suggests that morals evolved independently of religiosity. He is quite a character, that's for sure, but you definitely need to take him with a pound of salt. Some of his classification is also strange. Cocaine is a stimulant. It's a TOPICAL analgesic, which is starkly different from a systemic analgesic like Diamorphine (Heroin). However, more importantly Cocaine is a CNS stimulant, a sympathomimetic, whereas Heroin is a CNS depressant, totally opposite systemic actions.

Good luck filling in the hole...   a friend often used an analogy to describe addiction which was like imagining having a hole in your soul and using drugs, alcohol, sex, food, gambling, work or whatever to plug it up. But the drugs would only plug  the hole for a short while and eventually, through insanely repeating this process over and over, year in and year out for decades maybe, always expecting that it would eventually work,  the hole would only  grow bigger and get worse .This would be a never-ending spiral of futility into the abyss.  His suggestion was to try to fill the hole instead with love, compassion, understanding and gratitude, with good deeds to others, by being humble and having acceptance. It's worth nothing that Dostoyevsky's works have multiple translations. For Crime & Punishment, there is ONLY ONE excellent translation and that is by Sidney Monas. I had the great pleasure of contacting Mr. Monas many years ago and conversing briefly with him about his translation. I mostly wanted to thank and praise him and he was a gracious receiver of that praise. After that event I went and found another translation of Crime & Punishment at a local bookstore. I sat and compared them and the difference in prose was shocking! I don't have either of them here but for example, the mediocre translation might have read: "On a cold day he walked toward the bridge". But the Monas translation gave the whole book such wonderful life (and darkness): "It was a bitter day that found him approaching the bridge". I'm not giving this much in the way of creativity and I'm neither a Monas nor a Dostoyevsky.  Get the Monas translation in paperback - you'll love it. I read it when I was in a pretty deep depression and I remember identifying with Raskalnakov and how he fumbled around in his own mind. I never axe murdered anyone however, so that's a good thing I suppose.  Thanks Tim and thanks Jordan and Jordan I'm very grateful to see you and your mind doing well. Now remember: NO MORE PHARMACEUTICALS FOR YOU!!! Peace y'all.

One eighth of dried ground mushrooms is mixed with the other components and divided into 10 doses.  One dose is taken every 3 days.  I've heard it explained that chaga is the king of mushrooms while psilocybin mushrooms are the jester.  The jester can be kind and make you laugh but he can also be cruel and make you cry.  However, when the king is in court the jester behaves.  As such, chaga works to prevent bad (terror filled) experiences and keep the psilocybin in the medicinal zones.  Cacao is said to have similar effects while the reishi and cordyceps aid the development of new neurral pathways. This was eye opening for me.

A lot of people aren't very deep in how they think about God, they either think he's a low resolution sky daddy caricature or he has to be exactly as the Bible says he is through the totality of each Bible verse which mentions his features. Which is why on its face the quote seems so easy to disprove. It's also why people abhor the classic Peterson vid where he's asked if he believes in God and he completely takes the question apart rather than give a unidimensional yes or no. At the risk of sounding like a gatekeeper, it's a gnosis thing. You won't really get it until you have a profound religious experience where God gives you the corresponding apprehension, and even then it's a mere preview.

¬†@Svdgskjszgjsk¬† 100%. Every religion and spiritual belief system that has ever been for formulated by humanity has been an attempt to make materially cognizable/ sensible, the ineffable totality of totalities. Religion at its best is a very low resolution and often quite flawed and even counter productive endeavor in regards to achieving this goal. It's why ultimately each individual must find their own path to "God". There is no one, unifying truth that can be revealed to all people, in a manner that answers all questions, quells all doubts, and that all people can believe in and practice.  Once I realized this in my own way, in my own time, my mind opened up and I began to understand that the whole atheist vs. religious "believer", science vs. religion/spirituality dichotomy was false, and trying to "prove" the existence of God was impossible and pointless. It's found within, and when one finds it, it's quite liberating.  I think paying attention to some of Jung's insights really point in the direction that can lead to intuitive grasping of some of this, which is why Peterson is so fond of him. It's easy to see why more materialist/rationalist types would take issue with what Peterson says, especially the borderline obtuse, autistic "new atheist" types that hang their hat on straw man fencing, like Dillahunty and Harris. They're both extremely good at reductive argumentation, where they can deliberately ignore or be unwilling to engage in any abstractions (Harris even goes so far as to dismiss quantum potentialities by calling it "quantum spookiness") or symbolic representation as a sort of "tool truth" that uncovers deeper implications to be pondered. They reduce everything into materialism and ostensible "scientific consensus" and then play word games and use debate rhetoric to throw meat to the people listening that already have their minds made up on the matter, and who have extremely rudimentary ideas about religion/spirituality/metaphysics/the transcendent to begin with. They preach to their own choir. Peterson was brave for debating them, but it was bound to not look too good for him, since as good of a speaker as he is, he isn't the best (no one really can be in such constraints, if at all) at conveying all of this clearly, because it can't be. Let alone against people that effectively have careers formed out of sparring with ideologues and fundamentalists. I digress however. I used to really respect Harris in particular, but he over the last few years in particular has revealed his limitations to me.  For me personally, I was never religious when I was young, and wasn't raised in any belief system outside my parents being nominally lukewarm Catholics. I had my own sense of belief and prayed when I was younger, but never was too serious. I had my own intuitions about things when I was very young, but I never went to church or anything. By the time I was a late teen however (after having read a LOT about science and history) I had become a hardcore atheist/anti-theist. A misanthrope. I had learned all the evils of the church, and how many failed prophecies there seemed to be, and how many logical fallacies there is in the Bible, how much the New/Old Testament contradict one another. So thats all I needed to dismiss it all as bullshit. Now that I'm older and have read a lot of Jung, the Nag Hammadi library, the Bhagavad Gita, a lot of occult works, etc, I have had many of my decades old intuitions validated and fleshed out, FOR ME, and my belief has returned.

Hey Jordan, first of all, I started half way through the video, and have not yet gone back to watch the first half, but I felt compelled to pause the video and write to you. I very much hope you are well. I'm honestly on the verge of tears just watching the emotion that you are exuding. I feel this way because I do believe in love and that God is love, which provides hope, and as Hebrews 11:1 states, "Faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not apparent." I often think of faith as an indicator of good to come. I believe that all can be well for you. I feel very similar to you and I value your deep understandings and am hopeful for a long life of uncovering great foundational truths, and I want to see you do the same for as long as possible, and come out on the other side of whatever may be causing this suffering with great joy and victory. I hope that I am not being inconsiderate of physical ailment or other tragedy that may have occurred. I apologize if this is the case. To get back to the point, the level of understanding that you have attained may be burdensome, but the fears associated with them, or revealing them, possibly , which you seem to be considering in the video , may also be superficial to a greater good, and may also be completely fictitious or lack an ability to deliver on their threats, so it may not have significant relevance, and could be more of a test or trust building/faith building exercise. After watching, not reading, The Brother's Karamozov, the moral that hit home with me was an obligation to tell the truth, even in spite of fear of harm, maybe chaos. You are relating Dostoevsky to truth and I wonder if this could be why. At least in The Brother's Karamozov, he seems to be hopeful for a greater good. From the brief summary that I know of Dostoevsky's life, this must have been a strong belief of his, or else he was just relentlessly curious to his own detriment, or maybe I'm totally off, lol, I don't have all of the details there.  I just hope you are well and are able to express and discuss any concerns you may have with a confidant. I am fortunate enough to have a friend that I could go to in any situation that is concerning, they exist, if you don't have one yet. There is hope through all circumstances. I'd also like to bring up the idea of total surrender to God's will. This one is a hard one, but I've attained it, at least briefly, and believe it is a key tool in getting to know God. I love you, man! I don't know you or what you have been through or are dealing with, but I want you to know that I could forgive you for anything, I love you, and I value that you are around and hope to have that for the rest of my life... you're a little older, so nature would probably prevent that from occurring, but you get what I'm saying. Again, sorry if I'm way off basis with this. If so, then maybe it can at least allow me to another voice to speak up and say that I care about you.

Consciousness is balance between chaos and order. Without this balance, experience couldn't exist. Every point of view is another node of consciousness be it a human mind, a psychedelic fly, a tree or an atom and it all fits together to create balance and run this experience with the appearance of freedom of choice and the ability to experience anew. It is self perpetuating endlessly and there is no other options besides overall balance. Every point of view added together equals consciousness (balance) as a whole, also known as god or what ever you want to call it.  Intuition is the guidance we all have that leads us towards order, emotions are the guide towards chaos. Karma is the opposing force that guides us back towards balance when we go to far one way or the other. When you use emotions you move towards chaos, when you use intuition you move towards order. In the end however we all end up back at balance. Some of us take the long way. Everything in-between balance is an experience we are creating to entertain ourselves for eternity. There is no other way because without balance, you have balance anyway. With only direction towards chaos, you have destruction until eventual balance, with only direction towards order, you have order until eventual balance. There can and will only ever be balance, with temporary distortions called experiences.   We all experience everything eventually, that person who bullied you in school will be you one day, and you will have your reasons. Treat others well because they are you, even if you don't know it right now.

Benzodiazepine withdrawal experience from then, and my recovery, enriched my life in terms of understanding what that's like.   I was a registered occupational therapist at the time, for a decade almost, 45, had just made extreme headway in reversing an environmental illness relapse.   The experts said you see a lot of recovery in brain function in the months after, and at a year you pretty much have what you'll have going forward.  I knew from some patients with other brain injury causes, that's said to them, too, but I would see improvement years later in cases I kept in touch with. me and my friends did dmt once after a massshooting we happend to be, we sat down in silence, no one able to talk from all the shock and hell we went through when suddenly my friend stood up and said: i know what we need to do and we all took 2 hits of dmt, me not knowing jack shit about it, but used to drugs from all the raves over the decade...  it felt like meeting god and im not exagerating this, first layers over layers of everything i was looking at were starting to add up, one different than the other, picture over picture over picture, probably 5-10 times, my eyes started to hurt from all the information my brain had to deal with, because you looked at basically information 5-10 times youre used to, but i couldnt stop looking, it was amazing, then lights or better said impulses started to flow through everything, dead aswell as alive, plants, the woodwall, the friends around me, you were literally able to see the flow of energy through things.... im quite sure this is how the idea of the 3rd eye went into our world, because it really felt like opening a new sense that was always there but locked up.  the feelins were nearly unbearable just like looking at things, the emotions were at max intake, i wasnt even able to move, just sitting there and absorbing information, while my face started to hurt from all the frickin smiling, i never felt that happy ever in my life, not even in the slightest.  then as if a new chapter started after around 5 minutes sth i can only explain as a portal opening infront of me, light in the middle surrounded with waves of lets say a wormhole. and there stood shadows... of maybe aliens, maybe humans, maybe spirits, they were shadows in human form so im not sure what to call them and they looked at me aand where suprised i was standing infront of them, but they were welcoming, no fear, they felt like long knowing friends i forgot, maybe they were watching over me, were always there just me not being able to be aware... they didnt speak if i probably forgot, or they talked through emotions, energy, not with words, not physical in any way... they didnt feel like reality feels, the environment didnt feel like reality does, but still real in its way, just totally different.  when that chapter ended darkness started to appear, not sure if they were shwoing me this or its overall just what happens on dmt, because a lot of people tell stories about a deathexperience on it and thats exactly what it felt like, im 100% sure it was death i experienced, again not physical, it happend all like an outer body experience, my senses started to shut down, i couldnt feel anything, but in return i felt calm and at peace like never before, no fear, no happyness, nothing but absolute peace, being part of everything and the universe itself, i felt complete, like a puzzle piece in a greater picture.  after that everything came back to reality it was over after 15minutes, but felt like 3 hours, everyone of us looked happy, calm, no negative thoughts in any form for hours no one of us was able to think about what has happend because this experience was so out of this world that it overlapped the negative we saw hours before,  all of us went to bed after, no bad dreams, no bad thoughts, we slept like nothing had happend and the experience impacted me for weeks after, depression was gone, life felt easier, fear of death was not so fearfull at all.  i will never regret that, this was 5 years ago and it made me from an atheist to a agnostic type person, because i cant deny the reality i experienced, but i cant call it god, whatever it is, it is there and they are many and they are friends, more, they felt like family, with godlike abilities in a realm that is here, just not accessible for the average without help or training, ayahuasca/dmt for sure is the root of gods no doubt.

Jordan Pederson helps me to understand better the messianic world of the formerly drug-addicted control freaks. That's not a judgement, but an observation. We are all control freaks to a greater or lesser extent. We all have a 'dog' that we kick, even if it's just an idea buried in our minds. We all are addicted to something, some happy drug, some great crusade, maybe just something as simple as having clean water to drink. And when the drug no longer works, and great crusade is over and we turn the tap and nothing comes out but sludge and self-loathing, all that we're left with is God, Old Age and Death. When that happens, the old saw of No Duality and Non-Attachment is pretty poor tucker for the Soul to live on. It takes a Furious Will to dive back into Life, to leap back into the River, and let it carry you along. Every day a New Day of Existence, no Judgements and no Messiahs. Just live,... because you're a long time dead.

I think The Alfred North Whitehead quote is actually Nietzsche's; in Beyond Good and Evil aphorisms 6 he says   "Gradually it has become clear to me what every great philosophy so far has been: namely, the personal confession of its author and a kind of involuntary and unconscious memoir; also that the moral (or immoral) intentions in every philosophy constituted the real germ of life from which the whole plant had grown."   Or in aphorism 3: "After having looked long enough between the philosopher‚Äôs lines and fingers, I say to myself: by far the greater part of conscious thinking must still be included among instinctive activities, and that goes even for philosophical thinking. We have to relearn here, as one has had to relearn about heredity and what is ‚Äúinnate.‚Äù As the act of birth deserves no consideration in the whole process and procedure of heredity, so ‚Äúbeing conscious‚Äù is not in any decisive sense the opposite of what is instinctive: most of the conscious thinking of a philosopher is secretly guided and forced into certain channels by his instincts."  Not exactly the same but it's just the unconscious philosopher become the unconscious itself
