After immersing myself heavily in the psychedelic dimension...no matter what suffering I go through or witness now, I cannot shake that positive "smirk" my soul has attatched to it. That little post it in the back of the mind as a reminder of what beauty this reality really rests on... what it and we all are truly made of. I've been there so often I don't see it as more harmful than any typical recreational drug..just needs to be used properly and be looked at the right way with the right intentions. I've witnessed over 200 dmt trips, strong ones, only one that didn't make the person cry tears of joy and see life with more beauty. I've been in there plenty myself, dmt is everywhere in nature for a reason...it's a communication molecule, that's why Rick Straussman's subjects mostly said they saw beings that told them they "we're so happy we've found this technology, now we can communicate more easily." Not just that they saw aliens and it felt real, they had uncanny experiences that cannot be explained with probability or coincidence. And no Rick didn't get scared he just couldn't figure out wwhereelse to go, it's early reseach and pondering time. He did a follow up book though.  I agree with Jordan up to a point on psychedelics...I definitely don't think it should be recklessly administered. I'm telling you, Jordan Peterson himself would even benefit from one good controlled psilocybin dose in a regulated setting with a physician.  I don't like looking backwards to philosophers about psychedelics, nothing they've said is the right enough map of that dimension... It would be overwhelmingly positive for society to revisit them with more maturity...rather than ban them into insecurity, and fear them from what other thinkers feared...they're beautiful when done with the right people, in the right places and for the right reasons. Please don't let this negative view others have of them turn you away from researching the potential..male your own decisions, it seems Jordan is actually taking perspectives from the outside stories and what he's witnessed in others dealing with them. He should see from the inside before making judgements... Those "aliens" have a lot to teach us ;) losing the ego a bit and opening 'pandoras box' will do many so much good. Even that terror can be good to experience, those have been my most shaping experiences and have been the experiences that make me look at the world with love, not fear. I'm honestly tired of the fear stories and not the beauty....alcohol destroys lives, cigarrettes are cancerous and pointless...the poison in our food does us worse than psychedelics on the whole....makes me sad seeing such an intellectual miss this critical piece into bringing the walls down and shedding light on all the issues he's talking about in psychology...psychedelics would do so much more good than the bad he thinks...he needs to watch therapies of cancer patients using this stuff to lose their fears of both life and death, and not look at the scary side of it...those in the face of death are able to confront it with reassurance...it's been changing lives for the good...that's why the powers that be made it illegal...not because they love us. Terence McKenna also said this...don't let that amazing man's death and psychedelic work be in vein folks, to those that know him...sorry to those who read this rant üòÜ  Peace and L.O.V.E. - Living as One Vibrational Entity

I  feel as though It is hard to collaborate and make any sort of lasting relationships with this sort of person and yet I yearn for them. When I was in high school and college, I already knew I wasn‚Äôt a theist yet always hoped that when I met devout Christians that we could find common ground to support each other through positive discussions and meet to do something objectively positive for our community, school, etc. I would even attend bible studies and try to state my ideas on working together. However, when I tried to get anyone to agree that we wouldn‚Äôt put down or convert each other, they almost always distanced themselves or I refused to relent on attempts to change me. Ironically, it was my Muslim friends from various counties with fairly rigid theocratic governments who insisted we not make religion an obstacle to sharing healthy experiences together.  We would even check in to see if a behavior or statement was pushing any buttons, apologize and respect that boundary. Surprisingly, this mutual respect made us more curious about each other‚Äôs beliefs and cultures and we‚Äôd end up being less negative and presumptuous about ways of life that we‚Äôd been socially conditioned to more or less stigmatize and dehumanize. I wish I could timstamp this. But what do you think when he answered a question about what books he would recommend about personal development by saying, "I would not recommend anything to anybody". That's the  most unpatronizing sentence an author could speak out of all the possible sentences that exist.  You know what this means? It means that his intention is always unpatronizing but his tone is always genuine.  If he was not speaking in a disagreeable or assertive way at times, then he would be disingenuous, which you would certainly not want. It means that cetain things that he wants to communicate are best communicated in that tone which adds to a level of seriousness.  But yeah as for your question, what if you do not like the way he is saying things?  It can mean that he isn't really saying it to you (eg.an audience may exist that finds him the most impactful only in that way and that is the audience he most wants to impact. And you might not be super comfortable with that tone, but can still gain some insights). After all, you should always be wary of someone who tries to please everyone. Second that he might be poking at some bitter truth which is hard to come to terms with (growth can almost never happen in a place of comfort, isn't it?), which I think is not the case with you.

Ketamine infusion therapy saved my life, so I question Dr. Peterson's seemingly blanket condemnation of psychedelics. I suffered for decades with treatment resistant major depression and panic disorder / PTSD. I did years of psychotherapy, and tried over a dozen anti-depressants and anxiolytics none of which brought significant relief for me. It was literally hell.  As a last ditch attempt I tried ketamine infusion therapy administered by a Los Angeles clinic run by an anesthesiologist, Dr. Steven Mandel in 2018. A single treatment was all it took. I've been free of symptoms for 3 years now. So when Dr. Peterson puts down psychedelics, I question his wisdom in this area, earned or otherwise. Peterson claims to be an expert in psychopharmacology, yet also claims his addiction to benzodiazepines took him by surprise, and that he was unaware that long term use could cause severe withdrawal symptoms, even in low doses. This is well known (Google "Kindling"), so it's a very strange for him to claim ignorance about that. He expresses such forceful opinions about how dangerous psychedelics are, but the fact is they are far less dangerous than the most commonly prescribed prescription drugs, including the one  which nearly ended his life. I think what he fears is the insight that hallucinogens offer, insights which psychologists like him claim as their territory to defend as gatekeepers. Maybe some resentment towards a more effcient path to personal growth and wisdom at work here Dr, Peterson?  Just sayin.....

Thanks for this!!  Great interview!  I find it invigorating!  Regarding the discussion religion and the bible that starts about 55min:  Peterson has a hypothesis as to how/why the Cain and Able story is so deep... that maybe it was somehow transmitted in some sort of evolutionary way.  The traditional "Christian" approach would say that it is the "Word of God."  I know it may sound trite, but if the author of the Bible is a PERSON- the actual creator of the universe and humanity itself, then it's really not that surprising that we find the deepest human wisdom in its texts.  I have deep respect for Peterson's intellect and general insights.  I would say that in many ways I agree whole-heartedly with his assessments of "the way the world is."  However, I really think he would benefit from studying the writings of the highly intelligent thinkers across the last couple thousand years or so who actually were BELIEVERS in the Bible.  CS Lewis would be a great place to start.  He may actually have some familiarity already.  But it seems odd to me to try to draw out truth and meaning from the Bible without going the main sources.  Do you think you're smarter than Lewis, or any number of other actual Christian theologians?   Here's a link to a list of recommended books:   https://www.gospelrelevance.com/2017/07/23/5-books-that-influenced-tim-keller-during-college/  Also-  Tim Keller's own books would probably be a good source too.  His ability to relate the human experience to the Gospel and the Bible in general are excellent.  I have listened to many hours of Jordan Peterson, and I've never heard him propose any concept that isn't well-accounted for in Christian doctrine.  So I really think he should take a hard look at Christianity from the Christian's perspective.  He's trying to illuminate the truth that's already there.

On resentment- I watched what Peterson describes happen in real time in my life over the last year, and it was because of my own father‚Äôs wisdom (who has been dead ten years) and the knowledge of Peterson that I identified it and removed myself from it (albeit not when I should have, and thanks to Peterson, I learned from that and took responsibility for allowing it to go on).  This was a sixteen year friendship, and over the last year they felt more comfortable being rude to me in front of others, being disrespectful of my time, and when I spoke up about it, I was met with a complete lack of validation. They went as far to say that they felt something was wrong with ME.  These little things I allowed to build up inside me because like Peterson said, I thought myself to be better. I rationalized we were friends, not married, so I didn‚Äôt have a right to take things as personally as I did. And after all, it was a friendship that spanned decades, should I really rock that boat?  I played that game feigning forgiveness and letting go, until recently when they did it once again, and I stood up for myself firmly, and even at a point somewhat ugly. If I would have listened to myself much sooner, it never would have gotten to that point. And like Peterson, I thought about what they were up to, and I concluded that they just don‚Äôt see me as an equal, and they wouldn‚Äôt until I made myself one. I also learned that because I allowed it to get ugly, they will never see how their behavior is what pushed me to that point. I screwed the pooch on that one, and that was on me.  It‚Äôs amazing how right he is about that, and how what he taught me about standing up for myself allowed me to have the courage to do so. He made me more aware of the small things that turn into big things and to listen to those little nudges. I‚Äôm very grateful for that.  My friend did not like that I began sticking up for myself and the lack of respect built up inside me. I shouldn‚Äôt have done that. I‚Äôve learned that if someone isn‚Äôt willing to face something with you as it happens, don‚Äôt drag that out because then YOU become the perpetrator of your misery and you cannot blame the other for it.

¬†@72marshflower15¬† I appreciate the response, and I respect that you have suffered many trials. I might have been setting up a strawman, suspecting that things actually weren't awesome.   I think the main issue that people have is that JP is all over the spectrum with his ideas, so knowing his beliefs is pretty important to understand his use of terms. I have heard him explain his use of the terms conservative, liberal, progressive, etc. and I know that he is aware of the fact that words package meaning, which makes it difficult to find terms that don't carry extra baggage. I think it's important to note that he was talking about the New Democratic Party and a lone socialist member. He wasn't equating the two ideas. With the Ayn Rand point, he specifically points out that the librarian thought that JP would see through Rand. That implies that he wasn't a fan.   I think we have the same goal, which is to find truth and build from that point. If it helps, I was a Bernie Bro in a mental breakdown when I found JP. I am now a seeker, because I know enough about the totality of ideology to avoid certain labels for my beliefs (as well as the danger of drifting). I am weary of ideology because I know now that I don't know.    Given the plethora of personalities and archetypes, perhaps those following JP are just more aligned in their way of thinking, since no pattern of thought has yet yielded ultimate truth.   We are all wrong to an extent, but those acts that bring us to break bread with one another mark the point of union from which we can discover truth.

That book, that has not been corrupted by men, and promised within it as such and also challenges the reader or anyone to replicate the mastery of the language and no one has been able to, happens to be the Qur'an. Please don't vilify the people who supposedly follow it, in most of the world, they themselves don't really know it. Read it for what it is and then decide. Also know that the Arabic language, like Aramaic, which the Bible was written in is that much more nuanced and therefore context is everything. Oh and in the Aramaic Bible, (it may appear in others) the name of the last messenger was named and that he was to be followed, as man only, not god. There is no white bearded man in the sky. So I have had this idea for a couple of years now, that maybe Life (Capital L) is akin to the Fundamental Forces.  To get at this, I need to take a slight detour through the religious, but think about the aspects of God (Judeo-Christian):  Omniscient, Omnipotent and Omnipresent.  What were people trying to get at with this line of thinking about God/Existence?   Omnipresence (to them) is something like Space and Time... the Setting of Existence.  Omnipotence (all-powerful) is simply ability to do things (work), ie Energy (and of course, Power, technically defined, is the time rate of change of energy).  Omniscience...well this is very simply Information.  So, the Three (or Four) Fundamental Forces fit the bill quite well....they are, and in fact give us a whole new concept of, Omnipresent.  Without them, no form of Energy (including matter) or Information could exist or propagate.  Now, circling back to the original notion--Life as a Fundamental Force--this would be something akin to the Tao in religious terms (or another wat to think about it is the Water of  David Foster Wallace's "This is Water").  It flows through all things and returns, it does nothing and leaves nothing un-done, or some such. So, in my conceptualization, Life would interact with matter based on the complexity of it's structure, like RF energy to antenna array.  So, base minerals and such would have no interaction at all, while amoebas and other single-cell organisms would have more, plants more still, etc, etc, all the way up to the most complex structure we know of (the Human Cerebral Cortex--and we would throw the whole Nervous System in there too) having the most complex of all known interactions--Consciousness. Now, to me, this solves a lot of problems:   - The most fundamental question of Evolution: Why does life try?  - Why does it seem that often things would get discovered or invented in separate parts of the world at the same time?  - How is it that at least several times a year, I will have my phone in my hand to call my wife and it will ring and be her?   - How is it that I have had numerous, completely unuttered ideas for stories or movie scenes and they then show up somewhere in far too great of detail to be coincidence?  (not saying I have these ideas and broadcast them, but rather me and some other people are tuned into the same Idea Station at the same time???)   -It also fits in with the idea of Group hallucinations, as in that of Purple Lady from Mikhaila Peterson Podcast.  And now, it would in some way, explain the various forms of "Tree of Life" from around the world.    I'm sure other's would have many experiences that might fit this model as well.  If so, please respond.

Since starting to listen to JP and Order and Chaos structure of reality, I thought about another similar structure.  That of Status and Change.  This is the fundamental reaching up into the societal as Conservative and Progressive.  Both are absolutely necessary, right?  BUT, what is really amazing about the notion is that it can be easily grounded in the most basic, fundamental cosmology.  Status and Change could easily be one-word definitions of the First and Second Laws of Thermodynamics, respectively.

Jordan is courageous for asking critical life questions and seeking to answer them in public forums. His insights are a guide for real struggles which our society has assumed should remain concealed. I think someone could take his guidance to that point, but not further. His answers for meaning and purpose are based on deeply flawed assumptions which reflect his own personal values and experiences, and they lead to very ideological positions on the extreme right. The problem is that he takes vulnerable individuals and offers salvation presented as truth. These ideas centre on gender, status, hierarchy, institutions and social arrangements are biased, ignorant, bigoted and regressive. He offers only only viewpoint on what should be an open debate. It‚Äôs troubling to see broad thoughtless agreement, because politics, along with the self, are the two sites of agency and emancipatory action. Pay attention to his dilemmas, but know that his solutions are rigid, one-sided, and sometimes just wrong.

This time I paid attention long enough to try to figure out what the attraction was. That attempt mostly failed and left me mildly depressed for a day, so I have banished him again.   I do think that people who identify as conservative or traditional, and either consciously or subconsciously gravitate toward assertive figures, are drawn to his simple admonitions. He offers tidbits they can nod their heads to, and can try to latch onto. But how that morphs into the adoration is still beyond me, esp when I listen to him speak. At this point it's just a phenomenon with an underlying cause that I'm not really interested in trying to pick apart.   The real issues of our day are the extreme surge in human population, wealth concentration, resource depletion, and the related surge in CO2, and ramifications of that. And mostly the fact that even when people accept the realities about Climate Change, they want to continue practicing consumerism full speed ahead.

Dear Jordan Peterson, As it turns out you read these reactions I want to react to some of the things mentioned here. I did experience some psychedelic trips including a real 'nirvana'-experience; I can say there is some danger in it, but not so much what Jungians are afraid of. The real danger is actually going to our Christian/Western ideas to make sense of it: the idea that we have a purpuse in life, a mission; in the case of a nirvana-experience you will think 'mission accoplished', and you might be by your shadow seduced to end life. (You know at that moment that the world is illusion, that the choises you make actually don't mind, anything goes. For society these thoughts are of course threatening, especially if you want people to join the army and that's why they are forbidden.) Two things helped me here: the lectures of Alan Watts and a computergame (World of Tanks Blitz) which is a sort of analogy to life; where I could experiment with different behavoir and see what the consequenses are (including warnings to be banned from the game). It's not that I'm totally opened now compared with what I was before (but yes, the first period you are). The experience fades and you go on in a normal way, but with the knowing that there is a sort of dimension behind the world, that it's in essence a game, not to be taken serious (but sincere though, as Alan Watts explaines); it's about dancing and making music; and that makes that you are deep inside tranquil and more open to beauty and fun. The only thing here is that others won't understand you in these idea's and experiences; but in the end that's fine. They will know eventually...

His personal struggles are a lesson to us all that wisdom , intelligence and success should not be romanticized or idealized . We all have something that we must recognize, value and share.

The way I go about it is that whenever I differ, rather than thinking immediately that he is wrong (might be impulsive) I think, "What if I was to ask him a question about why he said that?". And that often leads me to think about ideas more deeply.  Trust me dude, if he says anything that is controversial (now I'm mostly talking about psychologically - and his perspective in politics might be psychologically aligned, which is often hard to find and hence useful), then there's probably a reason for that. It might be that he is wrong or it might be one of certain "bitter truths" that are hard to swallow. My way if thinking is to find solutions to those bitter truths so that they are no longer a hindrance. Maybe by asking him about it (I don't have that platform) or by inquiring myself. I can give examples.

I have an analogy that has served as a useful option when the chaos of resentment starts to enter my thinking. The analogy is called The Mountain, or the Sandwich in a nutshell it stems from a parable about a worker who has become dissociated from his life.    He works all day in a mute way, and struggles home through people that seem morbid and cruel. His whole day is justified by his favorite time of the day, when he sits, ceremoniously, down to eat his favorite sandwich. One day he comes home and looks in his fridge to find his deliciously looking sandwich is gone. Missing.  And he goes that night without the sandwich. The next day is unbearable and he cant take it. (That nights sandwich becomes just a sandwich)  So he decides to leave. In the middle of the night he packs his bags and loads his car with all his posessions. And almost in a trance he sets out toward this foreign country, not likes he's been there, but toward it like he knows its the right way. He climbs the mountain. for days and nights. agonizing muscle aches, dehydrated and sweaty he ascends the mountain. He shuffles into the cold part and becomes a shivering shuffling blur. He scales the heights and sleeps in a tent barraged by wind and snow. He freezes in his bag and moans in pain.  That night his equipment fails him and his lights go out. in the dark, He fights for a long time. aching. breathing hard. The dark accompanies the pain into a symphony of death. The strings of despair and drums of eternity wail within him... The next day is quiet, and the morning is drippy and sunny. He takes the summit in a uneventful way.  he just stands there for a second, looks out and sees the sight.  and then packs himself back down. He flys home, drives home, walks into the door, goes into the kitchen and looks into the fridge and his roommate who ate his sandwich replaced his sandwich with an apology note about not having the strength to resist the temptation. And hopefully he can forgive him. The man looks at the sandwich and sees it.  the sight off the summit comes to mind. And he closes the refrigerator door.  The story, to me, represents how we require resetting the meaning of things to a correct context by encountering real life and real death scenarios and how this helps us maintain sanity when in a realms of superficial value and monotonous struggling.  Only then can we treat the muted threats of inconvenience and passive aggression with the correct and dignified response.  We lose the ability to be courageous and steong when the world we live in shrinks our understanding of the world. We inhabit the realm to the degree we feel like a sandwich is big deal, such minute thinking can unravel a person into a heap of nerves and all concepts of "active in the day with clarity and strength" is lost. However with a mountain, or something that by comparison reduces the severity of the loss into a crrect context. then a sandwich just becomes a sandwich again and not a sacred ceremony that fulfills your life. The sandwich is not a substitute for the mountain, but a strange analog or a "summit of a hard day." And its the struggle and the ceremony that is most real in the sense that the content therein is transposable.  And  meaning is believed by the struggle itself. And the struggle cannot feel necessary without the dissolution of self, i.e. dying on the mountain in the dark, or being betrayed by a roommate who ate your sandwich and neither mountain nor sandwich in this respect is redeems life but both work together to operate the Person eating or Climbing them..  If you can treat the mountain and the day, the summit and the sandwich as twins that only merely recycle you into another day and another climb you may then deal with it like in the novel/film Fight Club, for which he said, "After a fight everything in life got the volume turned down, you could deal with anything." the onslaught of the dullness of life with a real courage, or renewed strength or discovered sense of how strong you actually are but make no mistake the climb does this. the day in day out does this. you are being redeemed merely by struggling.

Before this interview I watched a conversation between Sadhguru and a heart surgeon in India.  The conversation touched upon life's meaning and God's existence.  This narrative comes from Yoga and I thought I would just post it here to round out the conversation.  The idea of "God" is described as "universal consciousness" which fills everything in existence and beyond.  Humans exist within the physical realm of this universal consciousness.  Westernized culture puts too much emphasis on thought and emotions which are bound in the physical realm. There is a deeper state of mind called "chitta" which is able to move beyond thought and emotions and has complete access to the wisdom of universal consciousness.  When the question of the soul came up, Sadhguru said that word is too tainted and he preferred to call it Life.   Life enters the womb at 42-48 days of gestation at which point it "tests" the developing body for fitness.  If the body is suitable, it establishes itself at 84 -90 days of gestation.  Life enters the body through the unformed part at the top of the skull and may decide to leave at any point until the skull completely forms.  SIDS could be explained by the Life leaving the body for whatever reason.  The top two chakras (energy centers) of the body exist above the crown of the head and they connect Life in the body to the universal consciousness.  If the human lives in sync with the universal consciousness, the human prospers and the  body remains healthy.  If the human lives in dissonance with the universal consciousness, the human gets crushed under its weight.  I would really love to hear a conversation between Dr. P and Sadguru to discuss these ideas (I may not have expressed them accurately but I did my best.)  I also feel that there is a piece of a puzzle in these ideas which may help Dr. P resolve some of the conflict he is experiencing which I believe is causing him distress.

This was interesting. I subscribe to parts of what Jordan is preaching and on a fundamental level agree on some key points he wants to get across, but it was a bit jarring to hear his meandering answers where he talks a lot, but doesn't actually get to a point, just a mystical idea of a point. He also did not really listen to some of the questions and immediately jumped in, while also did not seem to be open to a dialogue when it came to the topics that Tim was very knowlegdable about. This might just be the contrast from other guests on the show, but I'm quite conflicted in my opinion of him - there's a lot value he conveys to people, but there's also a lot of assumptions and really big stretches of imagination when trying to connect some ideas and I just don't feel confident that he is the person to be trusted with the answers.   With that said, I wish him a quick return to full health and I'm glad he's out there. Might get the new book as 12 rules for life was a good reinforcing read.

This was ...interesting.  It's good to see divergent points of view.  That said, Jordan Peterson has a talent for making noise (beware of unearned wisdom indeed). He speaks against being resentful or angry, but there is an evident discomfort in how he expresses himself. He comes across as passive-aggressive, in that he can't make a point without criticizing someone, and it's usually "progressives", as if he's constantly debating an invisible foe (like the point he made about conservatives being achievers and activists being resentful. Really, queen?). With his "tell it like is" approach, it is no wonder he has become a neocon mouthpiece.  Still, he's an interesting character (this was more like a "60 minutes" interview).
